summary: This is an email chain between federal prosecutors discussing the ongoing review of Jeffrey Epstein's non-prosecution agreement by the DOJ's Child Exploitation Obscenity Section (CEOS). It reveals internal concerns about new victims discovered and debates whether to extend Epstein's deadline to comply with the agreement pending the CEOS review.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the federal investigation and non-prosecution agreement; his attorneys are negotiating compliance deadlines with prosecutors.

persons.name: Jay Lefkowitz
persons.context: Epstein's attorney who is communicating with prosecutors and expected to provide a summary to the DOJ's CEOS Section Chief.

persons.name: Acosta
persons.context: The United States Attorney who signed a letter amending the September 24, 2007 Agreement with Epstein.

persons.name: Andrew Oosterbaan
persons.context: Listed in the Cc field of the initial email, likely a prosecutor involved in the case.

connections.description: Lefkowitz is representing Epstein in negotiations with federal prosecutors regarding the non-prosecution agreement.
Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, amended the non-prosecution agreement with Epstein via letter.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Signed
events.description: An agreement was entered where the U.S. Attorney's Office would defer federal prosecution if Epstein pled guilty to state charges by October 26, 2007.

events.title: Original Court Date Deadline
events.description: A court date in Palm Beach County that was initially set as a deadline for Epstein's compliance with the agreement, but prosecutors indicate it is no longer reasonable to keep.

events.title: CEOS Review Meeting
events.description: The week when Epstein's counsel is expected to meet with the DOJ's Child Exploitation Obscenity Section (CEOS) for a review of the case.

events.title: Email Correspondence on New Victims
events.description: An email reveals the discovery of '6 new girls, plus another 3 probable victims in New York,' raising internal concerns about Epstein's plea deal.

keyFacts: Prosecutors had discovered 6 new girls and 3 other probable victims in New York, raising serious internal questions about whether Epstein should retain his favorable non-prosecution agreement.
The DOJ's Child Exploitation Obscenity Section (CEOS) was conducting a review of the Epstein matter, with a meeting scheduled for the week of March 31, 2008.
The original agreement required Epstein to plead guilty to state charges by October 26, 2007, but deadlines had been repeatedly postponed.
The correspondence shows internal tension among prosecutors, with one strongly questioning why Epstein should 'keep the same deal after all he has put us through.'

The U.S. Attorney's Office indicated it would extend the compliance deadline to allow for the CEOS review, but if CEOS disagreed with Epstein's position, he would have only one week to comply with the agreement.
